title: France lurch towards World Cup chaos yet again with calls for players to stage mutiny
text:
France's World Cup campaign is lurching towards trademark chaos, with the players being urged to stage a mutiny against their coaches ahead of Saturday’s clash with England in Yokohama.

While Jacques Brunel’s squad have already secured qualification for the quarter-finals from Pool C with three successive victories, they have been far from convincing and there have been growing rumours of unrest in the camp.

Reports in France have suggested that tournament captain Guilhem Guirado has fallen out with head coach Brunel and it has caused a power struggle.

Guilhem Guirado, the France captain, is said to have fallen out with head coach Jaques Brunel

Brunel's side have made it to the quarter-finals already but it has been a rollercoaster ride

Now, Mourad Boudjellal, the out-spoken owner of Toulon — who Guirado represented for several years, until this summer — has launched a searing attack on the France management and called for the players to initiate an uprising.

‘Take control guys, take the power, because there are coaches all over the place,’ he said.

‘Our team spirit is almost non-existent. Individually, we have players who are world class. Collectively, for several years, that hasn’t been the case.

‘Take control guys, because it is your history, your World Cup. You are there for your career and for your country. You are there for French rugby and to try to go as far as possible, to see if you can win this World Cup — but we will only get there if you take control.

Mourad Boudjellal, owner of Top 14 side Toulon, has called on the players to rise up

'Japan is a magnificent country to visit. Our coaches who are there, I invite you to visit Japan, go and look around, treat yourself and leave the players to tell their own stories because for years I have not understood the game plan of this France team.

‘Honestly, I don’t understand. Something is going wrong, so it’s over to you guys (players). Tell the coaches to go on holiday. Write your story yourself. There is a lot of experience, there are guys in this group who will certainly be major coaches in the future, so start to be a big coach today. Start today, kick the coaches out, take control. Tell your own story, we are ready to follow you.’

This is a familiar scenario for the French. Eight years ago, Marc Lievremont’s squad staged a rebellion after losing their last pool game against Tonga.

The players took control and France went on to reach the 2011 World Cup final — losing by just a point to host nation New Zealand.

authors: Chris Foy For The Daily Mail
